instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00239: What is 820-00239? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.A1707: What is A1707? A1707 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Late 2016, Mid 2017 with EMC 3072, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00281, 820-00928..

threads.title: MacBook pro <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power issue
threads.message:
hello,
i am new to this forum.
my name is Amir and i owe a electric repair shop in Israel.
i am new to MacBook repairs and have lot of knowledge  to complete.
as for now i have a MacBook pro model <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that wont start.
the customer probably connected 3rd party charger and now it wont power at all.
as for start i checked for blown component under my microscope and found nothing.
when i connect the charger to the left side, both take 5v.
when i connect the charger to the right side i have 0V on both.
can you please guide me were to check?

threads.title: MacBook pro <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power issue
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

Check diode mode to ground on CC1/2 pins of <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips from right side; compare readings with left side.
Do the same for LDO power rails of these chips; each one has 4 LDOs, consult schematic.

threads.title: MacBook pro <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power issue
MacBook pro <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power issue
MacBook pro <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power issue
threads.message:
ok, thanks
parts are not availble here....
i need to order from other country and it takes time.
in such cases, from your knowledge, do you think it will be enough? of maybe usually other componnent need to be changed?
i am asking so i will order it together and save time

threads.title: MacBook pro <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power issue
threads.message:
This is not an exact science.
Even replacement <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> can be bad (usual from chinese sellers) and you can waste time then, searching for another (inexistent) problem.

threads.title: MacBook pro <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power issue
threads.message:
can you, please, guide me were i can buy them?
i tried to order from your store, but you have only one in stock...

threads.title: MacBook pro <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power issue
threads.message:
Is not my store!

As recently posted in other thread, I prefer "board wings" to get original chips.
[URL unfurl="true"]https://boards.rossmanngroup.com/threads/<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>-liquid-damage-stuck-at-5v-on-usb.60302/[/URL]

Reading all the threads you can get valuable information.
Take notes from each post which think can help you in the future.

threads.title: MacBook pro <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power issue
threads.message:
so,
i got new  <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>  from beetstech.com
when i disordered  the old one i pulled out lot of pads from the board because of the glue.
i fixed them all and soldered the new one, but still i have 5V.
can you please guide me what how to proceed..

threads.title: MacBook pro <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power issue
threads.message:
You must be sure <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> area real good and correctly soldered.
Do you get 1V1 LDO for all them?

threads.title: MacBook pro <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power issue
threads.message:
all LDO should be 1.1V?
just to be sure, when you say LDO, you mean pins 2,12,35,53,75 on <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>?

threads.title: MacBook pro <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power issue
threads.message:
NO, I mean 1V1 LDO.
There are also 1V8 and 3V3 LDO rails.
You should be able to detect these lines by yourself, without writing entire names; 4 (four) on each <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chip.
